mn99:1.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
mn99:2.1: Now at that time the brahmin student Subha, Todeyya’s son, was residing in Sāvatthī at a certain householder’s home on some business.
mn99:2.2: Then Subha said to that householder,
mn99:2.4: Sāvatthī does not lack for perfected ones.
mn99:2.5: What ascetic or brahmin might we pay homage to today?”
mn99:2.6: “Sir, the Buddha is staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
mn99:2.7: You can pay homage to him.”
mn99:3.1: Acknowledging that householder, Subha went to the Buddha and exchanged greetings with him.

mn99:4.2: ‘Laypeople succeed in the system of the skillful teaching, not renunciates.’

mn99:4.4: “On this point, student, I speak after analyzing the question,
mn99:4.6: I don’t praise wrong practice for either laypeople or renunciates.
mn99:4.7: Because of wrong practice, neither laypeople nor renunciates succeed in the system of the skillful teaching.
mn99:4.8: I praise right practice for both laypeople and renunciates.
mn99:4.9: Because of right practice, both laypeople and renunciates succeed in the system of the skillful teaching.”

mn99:17.2: Which would have better flames, color, and radiance: a fire that depends on grass and logs as fuel, or one that does not?”
mn99:17.3: “If it were possible for a fire to burn without depending on grass and logs as fuel, that would have better flames, color, and radiance.”
mn99:17.4: “But it isn’t possible, except by psychic power.
mn99:17.5: Rapture that depends on the five kinds of sensual stimulation is like a fire that depends on grass and logs as fuel.
mn99:17.6: Rapture that’s apart from sensual pleasures and unskillful qualities is like a fire that doesn’t depend on grass and logs as fuel.
mn99:17.7: And what is rapture that’s apart from sensual pleasures and unskillful qualities?
mn99:17.8: It’s when a mendicant, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, enters and remains in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected.
mn99:17.9: This is rapture that’s apart from sensual pleasures and unskillful qualities.
mn99:17.10: Furthermore, as the placing of the mind and keeping it connected are stilled, they enter and remain in the second absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of immersion, with internal clarity and mind at one, without placing the mind and keeping it connected.
mn99:17.11: This too is rapture that’s apart from sensual pleasures and unskillful qualities.

mn99:22.14: I understand Brahmā, the Brahmā realm, and the practice that leads to the Brahmā realm, practicing in accordance with which one is reborn in the Brahmā realm.”
mn99:23.2: the ascetic Gotama teaches a path to company with Brahmā.
mn99:23.4: “Well then, student, listen and apply your mind well, I will speak.”
mn99:24.1: “And what is a path to company with Brahmā?
mn99:24.2: Firstly, a mendicant meditates spreading a heart full of love to one direction, and to the second, and to the third, and to the fourth. In the same way above, below, across, everywhere, all around, they spread a heart full of love to the whole world—abundant, expansive, limitless, free of enmity and ill will.
mn99:24.3: When the heart’s release by love has been developed like this, any limited deeds they’ve done don’t remain or persist there.
mn99:24.4: Suppose there was a powerful horn blower. They’d easily make themselves heard in the four quarters.
mn99:24.5: In the same way, when the heart’s release by love has been developed like this, any limited deeds they’ve done don’t remain or persist there.
mn99:24.6: This is a path to company with Brahmā.
mn99:25-27.1: Furthermore, a mendicant meditates spreading a heart full of compassion …
mn99:25-27.2: They meditate spreading a heart full of rejoicing …
mn99:25-27.3: They meditate spreading a heart full of equanimity to one direction, and to the second, and to the third, and to the fourth. In the same way above, below, across, everywhere, all around, they spread a heart full of equanimity to the whole world—abundant, expansive, limitless, free of enmity and ill will.
mn99:25-27.4: When the heart’s release by equanimity has been developed and cultivated like this, any limited deeds they’ve done don’t remain or persist there.
mn99:25-27.5: Suppose there was a powerful horn blower. They’d easily make themselves heard in the four quarters.
mn99:25-27.6: In the same way, when the heart’s release by equanimity has been developed and cultivated like this, any limited deeds they’ve done don’t remain or persist there.
mn99:25-27.7: This too is a path to company with Brahmā.”

mn99:31.1: When he had spoken, Jānussoṇi got down from his chariot, arranged his robe over one shoulder, raised his joined palms toward the Buddha, and expressed this heartfelt sentiment three times,
mn99:31.2: “King Pasenadi of Kosala is lucky, so very lucky
mn99:31.3: that the Realized One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha is living in his realm!”
